If they're still in the theater, they'll stay with it."<ref name="dvdtalk">{{cite web|last=Kleinman |first=Geoffrey |url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/interviews/chuck_palahniuk.html |title=Interview With Fight Club Author Chuck Palahniuk |work=DVD Talk |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123071414/http://www.dvdtalk.com/interviews/chuck_palahniuk.html |archivedate=January 23, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Palahniuk's novel also contained [[homoeroticism|homoerotic]] overtones, which Fincher included in the film to make audiences uncomfortable and accentuate the surprise of the twists.<ref name="fiction">{{cite news | first=Louis B. | last=Hobson | url= | title=Fiction for real | work=[[Calgary Sun]] | date=October 10, 1999 }}</ref> The bathroom scene where Tyler Durden bathes next to the Narrator is an example of the overtones; the line, "I'm wondering if another woman is really the answer we need," was meant to suggest personal responsibility rather than homosexuality.<ref name="DVDcom" /> Another example is the scene at the beginning of the film in which Tyler Durden puts a gun barrel down the Narrator's mouth.<ref>{{cite web | first=Stephen | last=Schaefer | url=http://mrshowbiz.go.com/news/Todays_Stories/991013/fightclubauthor101399.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010416022913/http://mrshowbiz.go.com/news/Todays_Stories/991013/fightclubauthor101399.html | title=Fight Club's Controversial Cut | work=MrShowbiz.com | publisher=ABC News Internet Ventures | archivedate=April 16, 2001 | date=October 13, 1999 | accessdate=December 2, 2007 }}</ref>
The Narrator finds redemption at the end of the film by rejecting Tyler Durden's dialectic, a path that diverged from the novel's ending in which the Narrator is placed in a mental institution.<ref name="empire">{{cite magazine | first=Damon | last=Wise | url= | title=Menace II Society |magazine=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |date=December 1999 }}</ref> Norton drew parallels between redemption in the film and redemption in ''The Graduate'', indicating that the protagonists of both films find a middle ground between two divisions of self.<ref name="reel">{{cite news|first=Barbara |last=Teasdall |url=http://www.reel.com/reel.asp?node=features/interviews/norton |title=Edward Norton Fights His Way to the Top |work=Reel.com |publisher=[[Movie Gallery]] |year=1999 |accessdate=March 24, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011095947/http://reel.com/reel.asp?node=features%2Finterviews%2Fnorton |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Fincher considered the novel too infatuated with Tyler Durden and changed the ending to move away from him: "I wanted people to love Tyler, but I also wanted them to be OK with his vanquishing."<ref name="empire" />
===Filming=== Studio executives Mechanic and Ziskin planned an initial budget of US$23 million to finance the film,<ref name="mav1" /> but by the start of production, the budget was increased to $50 million. Half was paid by [[New Regency]], but during filming, the projected budget escalated to US$67 million. New Regency's head and ''Fight Club'' executive producer [[Arnon Milchan]] petitioned Fincher to reduce costs by at least US$5 million. Fincher refused, so Milchan threatened Mechanic that New Regency would withdraw financing. Mechanic sought to restore Milchan's support by sending him tapes of [[dailies]] from ''Fight Club''. After seeing three weeks of filming, Milchan reinstated New Regency's financial backing.<ref name="mav3">{{harvnb|Waxman|2005|pp=199–202}}</ref> The final production budget was $63 million.<ref name="mojo" />
The [[stage combat|fight scenes]] were heavily choreographed, but the actors were required to "go full out" to capture realistic effects such as having the wind knocked out of them.<ref name=tribune>{{cite news | url= | title='Club' fighting for a respectful place in life | work=[[Post-Tribune]] | date=March 15, 2001 }}</ref> Makeup artist Julie Pearce, who had worked for Fincher on the 1997 film ''[[The Game (1997 film)|The Game]]'', studied [[mixed martial arts]] and [[pay-per-view]] boxing to portray the fighters accurately. She designed an extra's ear to have cartilage missing, inspired by [[Evander Holyfield vs. Mike Tyson II|the boxing match]] in which [[Mike Tyson]] bit off part of [[Evander Holyfield]]'s ear.<ref>{{cite journal | url= | title=It Bruiser: Julie Pearce | journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=July 25, 1999 }}</ref> Makeup artists devised two methods to create sweat on cue: spraying mineral water over a coat of [[Vaseline]], and using the unadulterated water for "wet sweat". [[Meat Loaf]], who plays a fight club member who has "[[gynecomastia|bitch tits]]", wore a 90-pound (40 kg) fat harness that gave him large breasts.<ref name="details" /> He also wore eight-inch (20 cm) [[elevator shoes|lifts]] in his scenes with Norton to be taller than him.<ref name="DVDcom">''Fight Club'' DVD commentary featuring David Fincher, Brad Pitt, Edward Norton and Helena Bonham Carter, [2000], 20th Century Fox.</ref>
The locations were in and around [[Los Angeles]] and on sets built at the studio in [[Century City]].<ref name="anarchy">{{Harvnb|Probst|1999}}</ref> Production designer Alex McDowell constructed more than 70 sets.<ref name="details" /> The exterior of Tyler Durden's house was built in [[San Pedro, California]], while the interior was built on a sound stage at the studio's location. The interior was given a decayed look to illustrate the deconstructed world of the characters.<ref name="anarchy" /> Marla Singer's apartment was based on photographs of the Rosalind Apartments in downtown LA.<ref name="comment65" /> Overall production included 300 scenes, 200 locations, and [[#Visual effects|complex special effects]]. Fincher compared ''Fight Club'' to his succeeding and less complex film ''[[Panic Room (film)|Panic Room]]'', "I felt like I was spending all my time watching trucks being loaded and unloaded so I could shoot three lines of dialogue. There was far too much transportation going on."<ref>{{cite news | first=Colin | last=Covert | url= | title=Fear factor is Fincher's forte | work=[[Star Tribune]] | date=March 29, 2002 }}</ref>
===Cinematography=== Fincher used the [[Super 35]] format to film ''Fight Club'' since it gave him maximum flexibility to compose shots. He hired [[Jeff Cronenweth]] as cinematographer; Cronenweth's father [[Jordan Cronenweth]] had been cinematographer for Fincher's 1992 film ''[[Alien 3]],'' but left midway through production due to [[Parkinson's disease]]. Fincher explored visual styles in his previous films ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Seven]]'' and ''The Game'', and he and Cronenweth drew elements from these styles for ''Fight Club''.<ref name="anarchy" />
Fincher and Cronenweth applied a lurid style, choosing to make people "sort of shiny".<ref name="comment65" /> The appearance of the Narrator's scenes without Tyler were bland and realistic. The scenes with Tyler were described by Fincher as "more hyper-real in a torn-down, deconstructed sense—a visual metaphor of what [the Narrator is] heading into". The filmmakers used heavily desaturated colors in the costuming, makeup, and art direction.<ref name="anarchy" /> Bonham Carter wore opalescent makeup to portray her romantic nihilistic character with a "[[Heroin|smack]]-fiend [[patina]]". Fincher and Cronenweth drew influences from the 1973 film ''[[American Graffiti]]'', which applied a mundane look to nighttime exteriors while simultaneously including a variety of colors.<ref name="comment65" />
The crew took advantage of both natural and practical light. Fincher sought various approaches to the lighting setups; for example, he chose several urban locations for the city lights' effects on the shots' backgrounds. The crew also embraced fluorescent lighting at other practical locations to maintain an element of reality and to light the prostheses depicting the characters' injuries.<ref name="anarchy" /> On the other hand, Fincher also ensured that scenes were not so strongly lit so the characters' eyes were less visible, citing cinematographer [[Gordon Willis]]' technique as the influence.<ref name="DVDcom" />
''Fight Club'' was filmed mostly at night, and Fincher filmed the daytime shots in shadowed locations. The crew equipped the bar's basement with inexpensive work lamps to create a background glow. Fincher avoided stylish camerawork when filming early fight scenes in the basement and instead placed the camera in a fixed position. In later fight scenes, Fincher moved the camera from the viewpoint of a distant observer to that of the fighter.<ref name="anarchy" />
The scenes with Tyler were staged to conceal that the character was a mental projection of the unnamed Narrator. Tyler was not filmed in [[two shot]]s with a group of people, nor was he shown in any [[over the shoulder shot|over-the-shoulder shot]]s in scenes where Tyler gives the Narrator specific ideas to manipulate him. In scenes before the Narrator meets Tyler, the filmmakers inserted Tyler's presence in single frames for [[subliminal message|subliminal effect]].<ref name="comment65" /> Tyler appears in the background and out of focus, like a "little devil on the shoulder".<ref name="DVDcom" /> Fincher explained the subliminal frames: "Our hero is creating Tyler Durden in his own mind, so at this point he exists only on the periphery of the Narrator's consciousness."<ref name="cinefex" />
While Cronenweth generally rated and exposed the Kodak [[film stock]] normally on ''Fight Club'', several other techniques were applied to change its appearance. [[Flashing (cinematography)|Flashing]] was implemented on much of the exterior night photography, the [[contrast (vision)|contrast]] was stretched to be purposely ugly, the print was adjusted to be [[exposure (photography)|underexposed]], [[Technicolor]]'s ENR [[bleach bypass|silver retention]] was used on a select number of prints to increase the [[optical density|density]] of the blacks, and high-contrast print stocks were chosen to create a "stepped-on" look on the print with a dirty patina.<ref name="comment65" />
===Visual effects=== Fincher hired [[visual effects supervisor]] [[Kevin Tod Haug]], who worked for him on ''The Game'', to create visual effects for ''Fight Club''. Haug assigned the visual effects artists and experts to different facilities that each addressed different types of visual effects: CG modeling, animation, compositing, and scanning. Haug explained, "We selected the best people for each aspect of the effects work, then coordinated their efforts. In this way, we never had to play to a facility's weakness." Fincher visualized the Narrator's perspective through a "[[mind's eye]]" view and structured a [[myopia|myopic]] framework for the film audiences. Fincher also used [[previsualization|previsualized]] footage of challenging main-unit and visual effects shots as a problem-solving tool to avoid making mistakes during the actual filming.<ref name="cinefex">{{cite journal |first=Kevin H. |last=Martin |title=A World of Hurt |journal=[[Cinefex]] |date=January 2000 |url=http://www.edward-norton.org/fc/articles/worldofhurt.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040227070738/http://www.edward-norton.org/fc/articles/worldofhurt.html |archivedate=2004-02-27 |dead-url=no}}</ref> [[File:Fight Club fear center.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=Blue and rough-looking tendrils stretch into a vanishing point in the middle; tendrils on the right side are visible, where the rest are obscured in darkness. Blue specks of matter float in the image. In front of the vanishing point are the words "Fight Club".|The opening scene in ''Fight Club'' that represents a brain's [[neural network]] in which the thought processes are initiated by the Narrator's fear impulse. The network was mapped using an [[L-system]] and drawn out by a medical illustrator.]] The film's title sequence is a 90-second visual effects composition that depicts the inside of the Narrator's brain at a microscopic level; the camera pulls back to the outside, starting at his fear center and following the thought processes initiated by his fear impulse.<ref name="comment61–62">{{Harvnb|Smith|1999|pp=61–62}}</ref> The sequence, designed in part by Fincher, was budgeted separately from the rest of the film at first, but the sequence was awarded by the studio in January 1999.<ref name="cinefex" /> Fincher hired [[Digital Domain]] and its visual effects supervisor [[Kevin Mack (visual effects artist)|Kevin Mack]], who won an [[Academy Award for Visual Effects]] for the 1998 film ''[[What Dreams May Come (film)|What Dreams May Come]]'', for the sequence. The company mapped the computer-generated brain using an [[L-system]],<ref>{{cite magazine | first=Mark | last=Frauenfelder | authorlink=Mark Frauenfelder | url= | title=Hollywood's Head Case |magazine=[[Wired magazine|Wired]] |date=August 1999 }}</ref> and the design was detailed using renderings by medical illustrator Katherine Jones. The pullback sequence from within the brain to the outside of the skull included [[neuron]]s, [[action potential]]s, and a [[hair follicle]]. Haug explained the artistic license that Fincher took with the shot, "While he wanted to keep the brain passage looking like [[electron microscopy|electron microscope photography]], that look had to be coupled with the feel of a night dive—wet, scary, and with a low depth of field." The shallow [[depth of field]] was accomplished with the [[ray tracing (graphics)|ray tracing]] process.<ref name="cinefex" />
Other visual effects include an early scene in which the camera flashes past city streets to survey Project Mayhem's destructive equipment lying in underground parking lots; the sequence was a three-dimensional composition of nearly 100 photographs of Los Angeles and [[Century City]] by photographer Michael Douglas Middleton. The final scene of the demolition of the credit card office buildings was designed by Richard Baily of Image Savant; Baily worked on the scene for over fourteen months.<ref name="cinefex" />
Midway through the film, Tyler Durden points out the [[cue mark]]—nicknamed "cigarette burn" in the film—to the audience. The scene represents a turning point that foreshadows the coming rupture and inversion of the "fairly subjective reality" that existed earlier in the film. Fincher explained: "Suddenly it's as though the projectionist missed the changeover, the viewers have to start looking at the movie in a whole new way."<ref name="cinefex" />
===Score=== Fincher was concerned that bands experienced in writing [[film score]]s would be unable to tie the movie's themes together, so he sought a band which had never recorded for film. He pursued [[Radiohead]],<ref name="DVDcom" /> but singer [[Thom Yorke]] declined as he was recovering from the stress of promoting their album ''[[OK Computer]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/thom-yorke-nearly-wrote-soundtrack-fight-club-2386137|title=Thom Yorke on how he nearly wrote the soundtrack for ''Fight Club''|last=Trendell|first=Andrew|date=3 October 2018|work=[[NME]]|access-date=4 October 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Fincher instead commissioned the [[breakbeat]] producing duo [[Dust Brothers]], who created a post-modern score encompassing drum loops, electronic scratches, and computerized samples. Dust Brothers performer [[Michael Simpson (producer)|Michael Simpson]] explained the setup: "Fincher wanted to break new ground with everything about the movie, and a nontraditional score helped achieve that."<ref>{{cite news | first=Amanda | last=Schurr | url= | title=Score one for musicians turned film composers | work=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] | date=November 19, 1999}}</ref> The film's climax and end credits feature the song "[[Where Is My Mind?]]" by the [[Pixies]].<ref>{{cite magazine | last=Spitz | first=Marc |date=September 2004 | title=Life to the Pixies |magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] | page=77 }} "[Kim] Deal: I think [that last scene in] ''Fight Club'' got 'Where Is My Mind?' popular. I don't know how people know our music now. For some reason, over the decade we got popular."</ref>
==Release==
===Marketing=== Filming concluded in December 1998, and Fincher edited the footage in early 1999 to prepare ''Fight Club'' for a screening with senior executives. They did not receive the film positively and were concerned that there would not be an audience for the film.<ref name="mav4">{{harvnb|Waxman|2005|pp=253–273}}</ref> Executive producer [[Art Linson]], who supported the film, recalled the response: "So many incidences of ''Fight Club'' were alarming, no group of executives could narrow them down."<ref>{{harvnb|Linson|2002|p=152}}</ref> Nevertheless, ''Fight Club'' was originally slated to be released in July 1999<ref name="blood">{{cite journal|first=Benjamin |last=Svetkey |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,271117,00.html |title=Blood, Sweat, and Fears |journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=October 15, 1999 |accessdate=April 30, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519221626/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C271117%2C00.html |archivedate=May 19, 2008 |df= }}</ref> but was later changed to August 6, 1999. The studio further delayed the film's release, this time to autumn, citing a crowded summer schedule and a hurried post-production process.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Leonard |last=Klady |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117503196.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |title=Fox holds the 'Fight' to fall |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=June 17, 1999 |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012002014/http://variety.com/article/VR1117503196.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Outsiders attributed the delays to the [[Columbine High School massacre]] earlier in the year.<ref>{{cite news | first=Christopher | last=Goodwin | url= | title=The malaise of the American male |work=The Sunday Times |location=UK | date=September 19, 1999 }}</ref>
Marketing executives at 20th Century Fox faced difficulties in marketing ''Fight Club'' and at one point considered marketing it as an [[art film]]. They considered that the film was primarily geared toward male audiences because of its violence and believed that not even Pitt would attract female filmgoers. Research testing showed that the film appealed to teenagers. Fincher refused to let the posters and trailers focus on Pitt and encouraged the studio to hire the advertising firm [[Wieden+Kennedy]] to devise a marketing plan. The firm proposed a bar of pink soap with the title "Fight Club" embossed on it as the film's main marketing image; the proposal was considered "a bad joke" by Fox executives. Fincher also released two early trailers in the form of fake [[public service announcement]]s presented by Pitt and Norton; the studio did not think the trailers marketed the film appropriately. Instead, the studio financed a $20 million large-scale campaign to provide a press junket, posters, billboards, and trailers for TV that highlighted the film's fight scenes. The studio advertised ''Fight Club'' on cable during [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] broadcasts, which Fincher protested, believing that the placement created the wrong context for the film.<ref name="mav4" /> Linson believed that the "ill-conceived one-dimensional" marketing by marketing executive Robert Harper largely contributed to ''Fight Club''{{'}}s lukewarm box office performance in the United States.<ref name="what">{{harvnb|Linson|2002|p=155}}</ref>
===Theatrical run=== The studio held ''Fight Club''{{'}}s world premiere at the [[56th Venice International Film Festival]] on September 10, 1999.<ref>{{cite news|title='Fight Club' gets Venice premiere |url=http://lubbockonline.com/stories/091199/wor_LA0734.001.shtml |accessdate=February 16, 2015 |publisher=Associated Press via ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'' |date=September 11, 1999 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216182818/http://lubbockonline.com/stories/091199/wor_LA0734.001.shtml |archivedate=February 16, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gristwood |first=Sarah |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/1999/sep/14/1 |title=Fury of fists |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=September 14, 1999 |accessdate=July 15, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107181749/http://www.theguardian.com/film/1999/sep/14/1 |archivedate=January 7, 2014 |df= }}</ref> For the American theatrical release, the studio hired the National Research Group to test screen the film; the group predicted the film would gross between US$13 million and US$15 million in its opening weekend.<ref>{{cite news | first=Bruce | last=Orwall | url= | title=L.A. Confidential: Studios Move to Put A Halt on Issuing Box-Office Estimates |work=Wall Street Journal | date=October 25, 1999 }}</ref> ''Fight Club'' opened commercially in the United States and Canada on October 15, 1999 and earned US$11 million in 1,963 theaters over the opening weekend.<ref name="mojo"/> The film ranked first at the weekend box office, defeating ''[[Double Jeopardy (1999 film)|Double Jeopardy]]'' and ''[[The Story of Us (film)|The Story of Us]]'', a fellow weekend opener.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1999&wknd=42&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for October 15–17, 1999 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=November 14, 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207223351/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1999&wknd=42&p=.htm |archivedate=December 7, 2006 |df= }}</ref> The gender mix of audiences for ''Fight Club'', argued to be "the ultimate anti-date flick", was 61% male and 39% female; 58% of audiences were below the age of 21. Despite the film's top placement, its opening gross fell short of the studio's expectations.<ref name="variety">{{cite magazine|first=Dade |last=Hayes |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117756713.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |title='Jeopardy' just barely |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 18, 1999 |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011204759/http://variety.com/article/VR1117756713.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Over the [[second weekend in box office performance|second weekend]], ''Fight Club'' dropped 42.6% in revenue, earning US$6.3 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?view=&yr=1999&wknd=43&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for October 22–24, 1999 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=November 14, 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001045128/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?view=&yr=1999&wknd=43&p=.htm |archivedate=October 1, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Against its production budget of {{nowrap|US$63 million}}, the film grossed {{nowrap|US$37 million}} from its theatrical run in the United States and Canada and earned {{nowrap|US$100.9 million}} in theaters worldwide.<ref name="mojo" /> The underwhelming North American performance of ''Fight Club'' soured the relationship between 20th Century Fox's studio head [[Bill Mechanic]] and media executive [[Rupert Murdoch]], which contributed to Mechanic's resignation in June 2000.<ref>{{cite news|first=Rick |last=Lyman |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/26/business/media-talk-changes-at-fox-studio-end-pax-hollywood.html |title=Media Talk; Changes at Fox Studio End Pax Hollywood |work=The New York Times |date=June 26, 2000 |accessdate=February 24, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121044934/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/26/business/media-talk-changes-at-fox-studio-end-pax-hollywood.html |archivedate=January 21, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
The [[British Board of Film Classification]] reviewed ''Fight Club'' for its November 12, 1999 release in the United Kingdom and removed two scenes involving "an indulgence in the excitement of beating a (defenseless) man's face into a pulp". The board assigned the film an 18 certificate, limiting the release to adult-only audiences in the UK. The BBFC did not censor any further, considering and dismissing claims that ''Fight Club'' contained "dangerously instructive information" and could "encourage anti-social (behavior)". The board decided, "The film as a whole is—quite clearly—critical and sharply parodic of the amateur fascism which in part it portrays. Its central theme of male machismo (and the [[anti-social behaviour]] that flows from it) is emphatically rejected by the central character in the concluding reels."<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Adam |last=Dawtrey |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117757863.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |title=UK to cut 'Club' |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=November 9, 1999 |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012002022/http://variety.com/article/VR1117757863.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The scenes were restored in a two-disc DVD edition released in the UK in March 2007.<ref>{{cite web|first=Philip |last=French |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/mar/04/3 |title=Fight Club |work=The Observer |location=UK |date=March 4, 2007 |accessdate=March 30, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141002232826/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/mar/04/3 |archivedate=October 2, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===Home media=== Fincher supervised the composition of the DVD packaging and was one of the first directors to participate in a film's transition to home media. The film was released in two DVD editions.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Scott |last=Kirsner |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117963617.html?categoryid=20&cs=1 |title=How DVDs became a success |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=April 23, 2007 |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713113330/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117963617.html?categoryid=20&cs=1 |archivedate=July 13, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The single-disc edition included a commentary track,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.foxstore.com/detail.php?item=105 | title=Fight Club | work=foxstore.com | publisher=[[20th Century Fox]] | accessdate=March 23, 2007 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207063232/http://www.foxstore.com/detail.php?item=105 |archivedate= December 7, 2008}}</ref> while the two-disc special edition included the commentary track, behind-the-scenes clips, deleted scenes, trailers, fake public service announcements, the promotional music video "This is Your Life", Internet spots, still galleries, cast biographies, [[storyboard]]s, and publicity materials.<ref name="special">{{cite web | url=http://www.foxstore.com/detail.php?item=986 | title=Fight Club Special Edition | work = foxstore.com | publisher=[[20th Century Fox]] | accessdate=March 23, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207064605/http://www.foxstore.com/detail.php?item=986 |archivedate= December 7, 2008}}</ref> Fincher worked on the DVD as a way to finish his vision for the film. Julie Markell, 20th Century Fox's senior vice president of creative development, said the DVD packaging complemented Fincher's vision: "The film is meant to make you question. The package, by extension, tries to reflect an experience that you must experience for yourself. The more you look at it, the more you'll get out of it." The studio developed the packaging for two months.<ref name=package>{{cite magazine | first=Marla | last=Misek | title=For ''Fight Club'' and ''Seven'', package makes perfect |magazine=EMedia Magazine |date=November 2001 | volume=14 | issue=11 | pages=27–28 }}</ref> The two-disc special edition DVD was packaged to look covered in brown cardboard wrapper. The title "Fight Club" was labeled diagonally across the front, and packaging appeared tied with twine. Markell said, "We wanted the package to be simple on the outside, so that there would be a dichotomy between the simplicity of brown paper wrapping and the intensity and chaos of what's inside."<ref name=package/> Deborah Mitchell, 20th Century Fox's vice president of marketing, described the design: "From a retail standpoint, [the DVD case] has incredible shelf-presence."<ref>{{cite journal | first=Wendy | last=Wilson | title=Fox's ''Fight Club'' delivers knockout package, promo | journal=Video Business | date=June 12, 2000 }}</ref>
''Fight Club'' won the 2000 [[Online Film Critics Society]] Awards for Best DVD, Best DVD Commentary, and Best DVD Special Features.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/2000awards |title=The OFCS 2000 Year End Awards |work=[[Online Film Critics Society]] |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305034947/http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/2000awards |archivedate=March 5, 2007 |df= }}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' ranked the film's two-disc edition in first place on its 2001 list of "The 50 Essential DVDs", giving top ratings to the DVD's content and technical picture-and-audio quality.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,279415,00.html |title=The 50 Essential DVDs |journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=January 19, 2001 |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014222005/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C279415%2C00.html |archivedate=October 14, 2007 |df= }}</ref> When the two-disc edition went out of print, the studio re-released it in 2004 because of fans' requests.<ref>{{cite news | first=Ron | last=Cole | url= | title=Don't let Kurt Russell classic escape you | work=Battle Creek Enquirer | publisher=[[Gannett Company]] | date=February 14, 2004 }}</ref> The film sold more than 6 million copies on DVD and video within the first ten years,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/08/movies/homevideo/08lim.html |title='Fight Club' Fight Goes On |last=Lim |first=Dennis |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=6 November 2009 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=1 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525024608/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/08/movies/homevideo/08lim.html |archivedate=May 25, 2014 |df= }}</ref> making it one of the largest-selling home media items in the studio's history,<ref name="what" /> in addition to grossing over $55 million in video and DVD rentals.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Jonathan |last=Bing |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117796888.html?categoryid=21&cs=1 |title='Fight Club' author books pair of deals |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=April 11, 2001 |accessdate=May 1, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011203553/http://variety.com/article/VR1117796888.html?categoryid=21&cs=1 |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |df= }}</ref> With a weak box office performance in the United States and Canada, a better performance in other territories, and the highly successful DVD release, ''Fight Club'' generated a US$10 million profit for the studio.<ref name="what" />
The Laserdisc edition was only released in Japan on May 26, 2000<ref>{{cite web|title=Fight Club [PILF-2835] |url=http://www.lddb.com/laserdisc/00045/PILF-2835/Fight-Club-%281999%29 |accessdate=29 August 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511061148/http://www.lddb.com/laserdisc/00045/PILF-2835/Fight-Club-%281999%29 |archivedate=May 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref> and features a different cover art, as well as one of the very few [[Dolby Digital EX|Dolby EX]] soundtracks released on LD. The VHS edition was released on October 31, 2000, as a part of 20th Century Fox's "Premiere Series" line. It includes a featurette after the film, "Behind the Brawl".<ref>{{cite AV media | people=Fincher, David (director) | year=2000 | title=Fight Club | medium=motion picture (video tape) |location=Beverly Hills, Calif. | publisher=Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment|oclc=45259209}}</ref>
''Fight Club'' was released in the [[Blu-ray Disc]] format in the United States on November 17, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ault |first=Susanne |url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6697620.html |title=PHYSICAL: Fox packaging reflects film's anti-establishment themes |work=Video Business |date=September 18, 2009 |accessdate=October 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925153719/http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6697620.html |archivedate=September 25, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Five [[graffiti]] artists were commissioned to create 30 pieces of art for the packaging, encompassing urban aesthetics found on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] and [[West Coast of the United States]] as well as influences from European [[street art]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Bradner |first=Liesl |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/09/fight-club-dvd-art-gets-tagged.html |title='Fight Club' hits the streets again, 10 years after the first punch |work=Los Angeles Times |date=September 12, 2009 |accessdate=October 15, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091018090448/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/09/fight-club-dvd-art-gets-tagged.html |archivedate=October 18, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The Blu-ray edition opens with a menu screen for the romantic comedy ''[[Never Been Kissed]]'' starring [[Drew Barrymore]] before leading into the ''Fight Club'' menu screen. Fincher got permission from Barrymore to include the fake menu screen.<ref>{{cite news |last=Villarreal |first=Phil |url=http://consumerist.com/2009/11/fight-club-blu-ray-messes-with-viewers.html |title=Fight Club Blu-ray Messes With Viewers |work=[[The Consumerist]] |date=November 18, 2009 |accessdate=November 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091219041511/http://consumerist.com/2009/11/fight-club-blu-ray-messes-with-viewers.html |archivedate=December 19, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Critical reception== When ''Fight Club'' premiered at the [[56th Venice International Film Festival]], the film was fiercely debated by critics. A newspaper reported, "Many loved and hated it in equal measures." Some critics expressed concern that the film would incite copycat behavior, such as that seen after ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' debuted in Britain nearly three decades previously.<ref name="slugging">{{cite news | first=David | last=Gritten | title=Premiere of ''Fight Club'' leaves critics slugging it out in Venice |work=The Ottawa Citizen | date=September 14, 1999 }}</ref> Upon the film's theatrical release, ''[[The Times]]'' reported the reaction: "It touched a nerve in the male psyche that was debated in newspapers across the world."<ref name="how">{{cite news | first=James | last=Christopher | url= | title=How was it for you? |work=The Times |location=UK | date=September 13, 2001 }}</ref> Although the film's makers called ''Fight Club'' "an accurate portrayal of men in the 1990s," some critics called it "irresponsible and appalling". Writing for the ''Australian'' newspaper, Christopher Goodwin stated: "''Fight Club'' is shaping up to be the most contentious mainstream Hollywood meditation on violence since [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''A Clockwork Orange''."<ref>{{cite news | first=Christopher | last=Goodwin | title=The beaten generation |work=The Australian | date=September 24, 1999 }}</ref>
[[Janet Maslin]], reviewing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', praised Fincher's direction and editing of the film. She wrote that ''Fight Club'' carried a message of "contemporary manhood", and that, if not watched closely, the film could be misconstrued as an endorsement of violence and [[nihilism]].<ref name="maslin">{{cite news|first=Janet |last=Maslin |authorlink=Janet Maslin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/15/movies/film-review-such-a-very-long-way-from-duvets-to-danger.html |title=Film Review; Such a Very Long Way From Duvets to Danger |work=The New York Times |date=October 15, 1999 |accessdate=April 30, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307015217/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/15/movies/film-review-such-a-very-long-way-from-duvets-to-danger.html |archivedate=March 7, 2010 |df= }}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]], reviewing for the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', called ''Fight Club'' "visceral and hard-edged", but also "a thrill ride masquerading as philosophy", whose promising first act is followed by a second that panders to macho sensibilities and a third he dismissed as "trickery".<ref>{{cite news|first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19991015/REVIEWS/910150302/1023 |title=Fight Club |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=October 15, 1999 |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070405103509/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F19991015%2FREVIEWS%2F910150302%2F1023 |archivedate=April 5, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Ebert later acknowledged that the film was "beloved by most, not by me".<ref>{{cite news|first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070823/REVIEWS/708230308/-1/REVIEWS01 |title=Zodiac |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=August 24, 2007 |accessdate=April 30, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522094413/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070823%2FREVIEWS%2F708230308%2F-1%2FREVIEWS01 |archivedate=May 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref> He was later requested to have a shot-by-shot analysis of ''Fight Club'' at the [[Conference on World Affairs]]; he stated that "[s]eeing it over the course of a week, I admired its skill even more, and its thought even less."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ebert |first1=Roger |title=The Great Movies |date=2003 |publisher=Broadway Books |isbn=978-0767910385 |page=xvi |edition=Reprint |url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Great-Movies-Roger-Ebert/dp/0767910389 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118125122/http://www.amazon.com/The-Great-Movies-Roger-Ebert/dp/0767910389 |archivedate=January 18, 2016 |df= }}</ref> Jay Carr of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' opined that the film began with an "invigoratingly nervy and imaginative buzz", but that it eventually became "explosively silly".<ref>{{cite news | first=Jay | last=Carr | url= | title='Fight Club' packs a punch but lacks stamina |work=Boston Globe | date=October 15, 1999 }}</ref> ''[[Newsweek]]''{{'}}s David Ansen described ''Fight Club'' as "an outrageous mixture of brilliant technique, puerile philosophizing, trenchant satire and sensory overload" and thought that the ending was too pretentious.<ref>{{cite journal | first=David | last=Ansen | url= | title=A Fistful of Darkness | journal=[[Newsweek]] | date=October 18, 1999 }}</ref> Richard Schickel of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' described the [[mise en scène]] as dark and damp: "It enforces the contrast between the sterilities of his characters' aboveground life and their underground one. Water, even when it's polluted, is the source of life; blood, even when it's carelessly spilled, is the symbol of life being fully lived. To put his point simply: it's better to be wet than dry." Schickel applauded the performances of Pitt and Norton, but criticized the "conventionally gimmicky" unfolding and the failure to make Bonham Carter's character interesting.<ref name=time>{{cite magazine|first=Richard |last=Schickel |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,992235,00.html |title=Conditional Knockout |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=October 11, 1999 |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122002302/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C992235%2C00.html |archivedate=January 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
''[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]]''{{'}}s Gary Crowdus reviewed the critical reception in retrospect: "Many critics praised ''Fight Club'', hailing it as one of the most exciting, original, and thought-provoking films of the year." He wrote of the negative opinion, "While ''Fight Club'' had numerous critical champions, the film's critical attackers were far more vocal, a negative chorus which became hysterical about what they felt to be the excessively graphic scenes of fisticuffs ... They felt such scenes served only as a mindless glamorization of brutality, a morally irresponsible portrayal, which they feared might encourage impressionable young male viewers to set up their own real-life fight clubs in order to beat each other senseless."<ref>{{cite magazine | last=Crowdus | first=Gary | title=Getting Exercised Over ''Fight Club'' |magazine=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |date=September 2000 | volume=25 | issue=4 | pages=46–48 }}</ref>
''Fight Club'' was nominated for the 2000 [[Academy Award for Best Sound Editing]], but it lost to ''[[The Matrix]]''.<ref>{{cite news | last=Hawker | first=Philippa | title=Oscar 2000 – Shocking? Not! |work=The Age |location=Australia | date=March 28, 2000 }}</ref> Bonham Carter won the 2000 [[5th Empire Awards|Empire Award]] for Best British Actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/awards2006/previouswinners/2000.asp |title=Sony Ericsson Empire Awards – 2000 Winners |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930201713/http://www.empireonline.com/awards2006/previouswinners/2000.asp |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The [[Online Film Critics Society]] also nominated ''Fight Club'' for Best Film, Best Director, Best Actor (Norton), Best Editing, and Best Adapted Screenplay (Uhls).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/99nominees |title=1999 Year-End Award Nominees |work=[[Online Film Critics Society]] |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305035048/http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/99nominees |archivedate=March 5, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Though the film won none of the awards, the organization listed ''Fight Club'' as one of the top ten films of 1999.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/99awards |title=The OFCS 1999 Year End Awards |work=[[Online Film Critics Society]] |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070419080449/http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/awards/99awards |archivedate=April 19, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The soundtrack was nominated for a [[BRIT Awards|BRIT Award]], losing to ''[[Notting Hill (film)|Notting Hill]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/entertainment/2000/brit_awards/625884.stm |title=Brits 2000: The winners |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC News |date=March 3, 2000 |accessdate=April 16, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308024131/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/entertainment/2000/brit_awards/625884.stm |archivedate=March 8, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], ''Fight Club'' holds a rating of 79%, based on 165 reviews, with an average rating of 7.3/10. The site's consensus reads, "Solid acting, amazing direction, and elaborate production design make ''Fight Club'' a wild ride."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fight_club/ |title=Fight Club review |website=Rottentomatoes.com |accessdate=2016-07-31 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529234841/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/Fight_Club |archivedate=May 29, 2016 |df= }}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 66 out of 100, based on 35 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/fight-club |title=Fight Club Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |date=1999-10-15 |accessdate=2016-07-31 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813091853/http://www.metacritic.com/movie/fight-club |archivedate=August 13, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
== Cultural impact == ''Fight Club'' was one of the most controversial and talked-about films of the 1990s.<ref name=tribune/><ref>{{cite news | url= | title='Fight Club' author Palahniuk to participate in academic conference at Edinboro University | work=[[Erie Times-News]] | date=March 26, 2001 }}</ref> Like other films released that year, including ''[[Magnolia (film)|Magnolia]]'', ''[[Being John Malkovich]]'' and ''[[Three Kings (1999 film)|Three Kings]]'', ''Fight Club'' was recognized as an innovator in cinematic form and style since it exploited new developments in filmmaking technology.<ref>{{cite news|first=Andrew |last=Pulver |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/nov/27/featuresreviews.guardianreview8 |title=Personality crisis: David Fincher's Fight Club (1999) |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=November 27, 2004 |accessdate=June 23, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507063437/http://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/nov/27/featuresreviews.guardianreview8 |archivedate=May 7, 2014 |df= }}</ref> After ''Fight Club''{{'}}s theatrical release, it became more popular via [[word of mouth]],<ref name=see>{{cite news|first=Damon |last=Wise |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2000/nov/02/features.theguardian |title=Now you see it |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=November 2, 2000 |accessdate=April 30, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509005602/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2000/nov/02/features.theguardian |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |df= }}</ref> and the positive reception of the DVD established it as a cult film that David Ansen of ''Newsweek'' conjectured would enjoy "perennial" fame.<ref>{{cite news|first=Nick |last=Nunziata |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/23/cult.films/ |title=The personality of cult |publisher=CNN |date=March 23, 2004 |accessdate=April 1, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208193757/http://edition.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/23/cult.films/ |archivedate=December 8, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first=David | last=Ansen | url= | title=Is Anybody Making Movies We'll Actually Watch In 50 Years? | journal=[[Newsweek]] | date=July 11, 2005 }}</ref> The film's success also heightened Palahniuk's profile to global renown.<ref>{{cite news|first=Bob |last=Flynn |url= | title=Fighting talk |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=March 29, 2007}}</ref>
Following ''Fight Club''{{'}}s release, several fight clubs were reported to have started in the United States. A "Gentleman's Fight Club" was started in [[Menlo Park, California]] in 2000 and had members mostly from the [[Technology Industry|tech industry]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2006-05-29-fight-club_x.htm |title=Fight club draws techies for bloody underground beatdowns |work=[[USA Today]] |date=May 29, 2006 |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070429060951/http://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2006-05-29-fight-club_x.htm |archivedate=April 29, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Teens and preteens in Texas, New Jersey, Washington state, and Alaska also initiated fight clubs and posted videos of their fights online, leading authorities to break up the clubs. In 2006, an unwilling participant from a local high school was injured at a fight club in [[Arlington, Texas]], and the DVD sales of the fight led to the arrest of six teenagers.<ref>{{cite news|first=Bruce |last=Rosenstein |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-07-31-violent-fight-clubs_x.htm |title=Illegal, violent teen fight clubs face police crackdown |work=USA Today |date=August 1, 2006 |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427223344/http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-07-31-violent-fight-clubs_x.htm |archivedate=April 27, 2007 |df= }}</ref> An unsanctioned fight club was also started at [[Princeton University]], where matches were held on campus.<ref>{{cite news | url= | title=At Princeton, no punches pulled | work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] | date=June 6, 2001 }}</ref> The film was suspected of influencing [[Luke Helder]], a college student who planted [[pipe bomb]]s in mailboxes in 2002. Helder's goal was to create a [[smiley]] pattern on the map of the United States, similar to the scene in ''Fight Club'' in which a building is vandalized to have a smiley on its exterior.<ref>{{cite magazine | first=C. T. | last=Rossi | url= | title=Father Absence Key to Male Masculinity Crisis | publisher=[[News World Communications]]|magazine=[[Insight (magazine)|Insight on the News]] | date=June 10, 2002 }}</ref> On July 16, 2009, a 17-year-old who had formed his own fight club in [[Manhattan]] was charged with detonating a homemade bomb outside a [[Starbucks Coffee]] shop in the [[Upper East Side]]. The [[New York City Police Department]] reported the suspect was trying to emulate "Project Mayhem".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jul/16/starbucks-bombing-blamed-on-fight-club-fancy/ |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Washington Times]] |title=Starbucks bombing blamed on 'Fight Club' fancy |date=July 16, 2009 |accessdate=July 18, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718151230/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jul/16/starbucks-bombing-blamed-on-fight-club-fancy/ |archivedate=July 18, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
A video game adaptation of the film, titled ''[[Fight Club (video game)|Fight Club]]'', was released by [[Vivendi]] in 2004 for the [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], and for [[mobile phone]]s. The game was a critical and commercial failure, and was panned by such publications and websites as [[GameSpot]], ''[[Game Informer]]'', and [[IGN]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Kasavin |first=Greg |date=11 November 2004 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/fight-club-review/1900-6112987/ |title=Fight Club Review (PS2, Xbox) |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=6 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111105808/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/fight-club-review/1900-6112987/ |archivedate=January 11, 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Ryckert |first=Dan |title=Top Ten Fighting Games We'd Like to Forget |magazine=Game Informer |issue=216 |date=April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Perry |first=Douglass C. |date=15 November 2004 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/11/16/fight-club-2 |title=Fight Club (PS2, Xbox) |publisher=IGN |accessdate=6 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821025436/http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/11/16/fight-club-2 |archivedate=August 21, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
In 2003, ''Fight Club'' was listed as one of the "50 Best Guy Movies of All Time" by ''[[Men's Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dirks |first=Tim |url=http://www.filmsite.org/guyfilms.html |title=50 Best Guy Movies of All Time |work=Filmsite |publisher=[[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]] |accessdate=April 27, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212144705/http://www.filmsite.org/guyfilms.html |archivedate=February 12, 2009 |df= }}</ref> In 2006 and 2008, ''Fight Club'' was voted by ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' readers as the eighth and tenth greatest film of all time, respectively.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=The 100 Greatest Movies Of All Time|page=96|magazine=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date=January 30, 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|page=98|title=The 201 Greatest Movies Of All Time|magazine=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date=January 2006}}</ref> ''[[Total Film]]'' ranked ''Fight Club'' as "The Greatest Film of our Lifetime" in 2007 during the magazine's tenth anniversary.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Ten Greatest Films of the Past Decade | page=98 | journal=[[Total Film]] |date=April 2007 }}</ref> In 2007, ''[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]]'' selected Tyler Durden's line, "The first rule of fight club is you do not talk about fight club," as the 27th greatest movie line of all time.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The 100 Greatest Movie Lines |magazine=[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]] | url = http://www.premiere.com/gallery.aspx?section_id=66&webtrends_section=best&article_id=3713&section_prefix=best&window_id=1&gallery_id=298&page_number=1&seq=74&cnt=76 | accessdate=May 13, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071114183306/http://www.premiere.com/gallery.aspx?section_id=66&webtrends_section=best&article_id=3713&section_prefix=best&window_id=1&gallery_id=298&page_number=1&seq=74&cnt=76 |archivedate = November 14, 2007 | deadurl = yes}}</ref> In 2008, readers of ''Empire'' ranked Tyler Durden eighth on a list of the 100 Greatest Movie Characters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/100-greatest-movie-characters/default.asp?c=1 |title=The 100 Greatest Movie Characters – 8. Tyler Durden |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=December 1, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516095104/http://www.empireonline.com/100-greatest-movie-characters/default.asp?c=1 |archivedate=May 16, 2011 |df= }}</ref> ''Empire'' also identified ''Fight Club'' as the 10th greatest movie of all time in its 2008 issue ''The 500 Greatest Movies of All Time''.<ref name=empiremag>{{cite news|url=http://www.empireonline.com/500/94.asp |title=Empire's 500 Greatest Movies of All Time |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=January 3, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101010231/http://www.empireonline.com/500/94.asp |archivedate=November 1, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In 2010, two viral [[Mashup (video)|mash-up videos]] featuring ''Fight Club'' were released. ''Ferris Club'' was a mash-up of ''Fight Club'' and the 1986 film ''[[Ferris Bueller's Day Off]]''. It portrayed Ferris as Tyler Durden and Cameron as the narrator, "claiming to see the real psychological truth behind the [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]] classic".<ref>{{cite news|last=Chivers |first=Tom |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/7910395/Jane-Austens-Fight-Club-is-viral-web-video-hit.html |title=Jane Austen's Fight Club is viral web video hit |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=July 26, 2010 |accessdate=October 19, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812184549/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/7910395/Jane-Austens-Fight-Club-is-viral-web-video-hit.html |archivedate=August 12, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The second video ''Jane Austen's Fight Club'' also gained [[popularity]] online as a mash-up of ''Fight Club''{{'}}s fighting [[wikt:rule|rule]]s and the characters created by 19th century novelist [[Jane Austen]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Staskiewicz |first=Keith |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/07/30/jane-austens-fight-club/ |title=I am Jane's pinching corset: We talk to the creator of 'Jane Austen's Fight Club' |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100804063804/http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/07/30/jane-austens-fight-club/ |archivedate=August 4, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
===American Film Institute nominations=== * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]]: "First rule of Fight Club is—you do not talk about Fight Club."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100years/quotes400.pdf |format=PDF |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes Nominees |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-31 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628043426/http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/quotes400.pdf |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |df= }}</ref> * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100years/Movies_ballot_06.pdf |format=PDF |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition) Ballot |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-31 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328082204/http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/Movies_ballot_06.pdf |archivedate=March 28, 2014 |df= }}</ref>

{{About|the (sometimes historical) social practice of children being raised by families not their own|the modern child welfare system of placing children in state custody in the homes of temporary caregivers|Foster care}} {{Globalize|date=July 2010}}
'''Fosterage''', the practice of a family bringing up a child not their own, differs from [[adoption]] in that the child's parents, not the foster-parents, remain the acknowledged parents. In many modern western societies [[foster care]] can be organised by the state to care for children with troubled family backgrounds, usually on a temporary basis. In many pre-modern societies fosterage was a form of [[patronage]], whereby influential families cemented political relationships by bringing up each other's children, similar to [[arranged marriage]]s, also based on dynastic or alliance calculations.
This practice was once common in Ireland, Wales, and Scotland.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fosterage|title=Fosterage |publisher= Merriam-Webster |accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref>
==Fosterage in the Hebrides== In his ''[[A Journey to the Western Isles of Scotland]]'' (1775), writer [[Samuel Johnson]] described the fosterage custom as he saw it practised.<ref>''A Journey to the Western Isles of Scotland'' by Samuel Johnson. 1775 edition. [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/2/0/6/2064/2064.txt Gutenberg text] accessed May 23, 2008</ref>
{{cquote|There still remains in the [[Hebrides|Islands]], though it is passing fast away, the custom of fosterage. A [[Laird]], a man of wealth and eminence, sends his child, either male or female, to a [[tacksman]], or tenant, to be fostered. It is not always his own tenant, but some distant friend that obtains this honour; for an honour such a trust is very reasonably thought. The terms of fosterage seem to vary in different islands. In [[Isle of Mull|Mull]], the father sends with his child a certain number of cows, to which the same number is added by the fosterer. The father appropriates a proportionable extent of ground, without rent, for their pasturage. If every cow brings a calf, half belongs to the fosterer, and half to the child; but if there be only one calf between two cows, it is the child's, and when the child returns to the parent, it is accompanied by all the cows given, both by the father and by the fosterer, with half of the increase of the stock by propagation. These beasts are considered as a portion, and called Macalive cattle, of which the father has the produce, but is supposed not to have the full property, but to owe the same number to the child, as a portion to the daughter, or a stock for the son.
Children continue with the fosterer perhaps six years, and cannot, where this is the practice, be considered as burdensome. The fosterer, if he gives four cows, receives likewise four, and has, while the child continues with him, grass for eight without rent, with half the calves, and all the milk, for which he pays only four cows when he dismisses his Dalt, for that is the name for a foster child.
Fosterage is, I believe, sometimes performed upon more liberal terms. Our friend, the young Laird of Col, was fostered by Macsweyn of Grissipol. Macsweyn then lived a tenant to Sir James Macdonald in the Isle of Sky; and therefore Col, whether he sent him cattle or not, could grant him no land. The Dalt, however, at his return, brought back a considerable number of Macalive cattle, and of the friendship so formed there have been good effects. When Macdonald raised his rents, Macsweyn was, like other tenants, discontented, and, resigning his farm, removed from Sky to Col, and was established at Grissipol.}}
==Fosterage in Medieval Iceland== Fosterage or "fostering" is frequently referred to in the medieval [[Sagas of Icelanders]]. Original family ties and rights of inheritance were not affected, nor was it required for the fostered child to be an orphan or for the biological father to be deceased. Moreover, the fostering of another man's child was regarded as a source of honor to the birth father; and conventionally the fostering party was of inferior social status to the biological father. An exception to this convention is found in [[Njáls saga]], where [[Njáll Þorgeirsson|Njál Thorgeirsson]], a very prominent man, fosters Hoskuld, the son of Thrain Sigfusson, after the death of Thrain in battle.
Portions of Ireland, Scotland and the Hebrides were ruled for long periods of time by Norse invaders during the Middle Ages; but it is unknown which culture was the original source of the custom of fosterage.
==Literary fosterage== In [[Ancient Ireland]], [[ollam]]s taught children either for payment or for no compensation. Children were taught a particular trade and treated like family; their original family ties were often severed.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.libraryireland.com/Brehon-Laws/Fosterage.php|title=Fosterage in Ancient Ireland|publisher=Library Ireland|accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref>
==Fosterage in other cultures==
There was similar custom in the [[Caucasus]], called Atalik - [[:ru:Аталычество]].
